etymologies: late 17th century; earliest use found in Samuel Pordage (bap. 1633, d. c1691), poet and translator. From post-classical Latin sonorificus from classical Latin sonōri-, stem of sonor sound + -ficus

definitions: Producing, or capable of producing, sound.

notes.text: In later use frequently with reference to the production of sound by parts of an animal's body other than vocal organs.
